pageProps.body:
Inhomogeneous Equations

Recall that an inhomogeneous equation is one that does not have y=0y=0y=0 as a solution; e.g. 5y′−3y=105y' - 3y = 105y′−3y=10 is inhomogeneous, having an added term 10 on the right-hand side compared to the homogeneous equation. These added terms are "forcing" terms.

Method. The particular integral solution. This method applies to inhomogeneous equations where one side is completely homogeneous with constant coefficients (all terms contain yyy or a derivative of yyy) and the other side is a function of xxx. For instance, 2y′+3y=3x2+x2y' + 3y = 3x^2 + x2y′+3y=3x2+x is applicable.

The method for solving this type of equation is to first solve the equation as though it was homogeneous (turn the right-hand side to 0), which yields the complementary function, then guessing one particular solution to the equation, known as a particular integral. The general solution is the sum of both.

Take the following radioactive decay model as an example:

Example. A radioactive isotope AAA decays at a rate proportional to the remaining amount of nuclei in its sample, aaa, into isotope BBB, which further decays at a rate proportional to the remaining amount of nuclei in its sample, bbb.

Given that the constants of proportionality are kak_aka​ and kbk_bkb​ respectively, and that the initial number of nuclei present in each sample are a0a_0a0​ and 0 respectively, determine an expression for the remaining nuclei in sample BBB, b(t)b(t)b(t).

We have

dadt=−kaadbdt=kaa−kbb\begin{aligned} \frac{da}{dt} &= -k_a a \\ \frac{db}{dt} &= k_a a - k_b b \end{aligned}dtda​dtdb​​=−ka​a=ka​a−kb​b​

Solving the first equation yields a=λe−kata = \lambda e^{-k_a t}a=λe−ka​t for some constant λ\lambdaλ, with the initial condition that when t=0t=0t=0, a=a0a=a_0a=a0​; thus, a=a0e−kata=a_0 e^{-k_a t}a=a0​e−ka​t. Substituting into the second equation yields dbdt=a0e−kat−kbb\frac{db}{dt} = a_0 e^{-k_a t} - k_b bdtdb​=a0​e−ka​t−kb​b, or b′+kbb=a0e−katb' + k_b b = a_0 e^{-k_a t}b′+kb​b=a0​e−ka​t.

The homogeneous equation has solution λe−kbt\lambda e^{-k_b t}λe−kb​t for any constant λ\lambdaλ. Try b=αe−kat,b′=−kaαe−katb = \alpha e^{-k_a t}, b' = -k_a \alpha e^{-k_a t}b=αe−ka​t,b′=−ka​αe−ka​t for the particular integral; plugging this into the equation gives −kaαe−kat+kbαe−kat=a0e−kat-k_a \alpha e^{-k_a t} + k_b \alpha e^{-k_a t} = a_0 e^{-k_a t}−ka​αe−ka​t+kb​αe−ka​t=a0​e−ka​t, and dividing both sides by e−kate^{-k_a t}e−ka​t gives (kb−ka)α=a0,α=a0kb−ka(k_b - k_a)\alpha = a_0, \alpha = \frac{a_0}{k_b - k_a}(kb​−ka​)α=a0​,α=kb​−ka​a0​​.

We also need b(0)=0b(0) = 0b(0)=0, so if b=a0kb−kae−kat+λe−kbtb = \frac{a_0}{k_b - k_a}e^{-k_a t} + \lambda e^{-k_b t}b=kb​−ka​a0​​e−ka​t+λe−kb​t, a0kb−ka+λ=0\frac{a_0}{k_b - k_a} + \lambda = 0kb​−ka​a0​​+λ=0, so λ=−a0kb−ka\lambda = -\frac{a_0}{k_b - k_a}λ=−kb​−ka​a0​​. Thus b=a0kb−ka(e−kat−e−kbt).b = \frac{a_0}{k_b - k_a}(e^{-k_a t} - e^{-k_b t}).b=kb​−ka​a0​​(e−ka​t−e−kb​t).
